data.title: Adrien Brody on Cars, Style & Showbiz
data.meta_description: Actor Adrien Brody on being chased by his girlfriend's ex-boyfriend in his first Volvo, customizing Ford Mustangs on the cheap, dressing for all occasions, and what he loves most about acting in movies.
data.text:
(chilled-out guitar music)

My first car, I mean, I... Man...

I had a Volvo 164E.

that I bought from a neighbor, a friend of mine,

for 50 bucks and it didn't go in reverse.

I literally got chased by an ex-girfriend's

ex-boyfriend in the Bronx in that car.

And, you know. There was no going backwards, you know.

You've got to make sure you know where you're going.

(laughter)

At 17, wow. And then I had a Mustang Mach 1,

which was really my favorite at that time.

If I'd go back to those days, I'd make something

pretty fly that was, you know, my Mustang was 850 bucks.

And, I learned to do the body work, I learned

to tint the windows and put in the sound system.

I did a matte paint job then, well, that paint job

was done because you couldn't afford lacquer.

Couldn't afford a polished paint job, but you

had to show your own unique style that was

different from others, making due and making something

pretty unique and fresh.

That was a big part of growing up in New York and Queens.

Well...

to comment on fashion is a faux-pa I think.

You know, look, I feel really grateful because

I've been welcomed into the fashion community,

and I think there's a lot of artistry in there.

And creativity, and...

I don't think about it too much past that.

These days, I kind of

am happy in jeans

and a t-shirt and a hoodie, and then if I'm at an event

I'll put on a three-piece suit and wear that casually.

You know, I just try to keep

it all casual even if it's a tuxedo.

There's a formality in certain attire, and I think

regardless of that, you've got to

feel comfortable and natural with it.

I think the beauty of making movies and the nature

of film is that you're under the gun

And...

you're all in, and then you're completely

done with it, and it's gone.

And it's really, it's gone, and that guy is gone.

And who I was then is gone, and it's really nice

to jump from that into something else.

If you look at the kind of roles that I play

back-to-back, that's what's exciting.

You know, playing Houdini for instance,

in the turn of the century, with a very thick

kind of New York accent, almost, and then

jumping to play a psychologist in Melbourne

who is Australian, within a matter of weeks.

My parents didn't understand me on the phone.

It's really, such a remarkable, ah, profession

if you're in touch with it, and you're, and my job

requirement is to put myself in other people's shoes.

And the only way you do that is to understand

the person you are meant to portray.

And, it's taught me a lot.
